body:
Your welcome. In your case it would look something like this:

``` python
et = ExternalTaskSensor(
  external_dag_id='upstream_dag',
  external_task_id='upstream',
  dag=dag, 
  task_id='wait_for_upstream')

down definition here

down.set_upstream(et)
```
Thank you both!

Still dont work,Do I need to set execution_date? both the tasks's execution_date I'm running is 2015-08-31 00:00:00

``` python
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

from airflow.operators import BashOperator, EmailOperator
from airflow.models import DAG
from airflow.operators import ExternalTaskSensor

MAIL_TO = [
    'tonylee0329@gmail.com'
]

args = {
    'owner': 'tony',
    'start_date': datetime.strptime('2015-08-31 12:00:00', '%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S'),
    'email': MAIL_TO,
    'email_on_failure': True,
    'email_on_retry': True,
    'retries': 3,
    'retry_interval': timedelta(minutes=5),
    'schedule_interval': timedelta(minutes=5),
}

dag = DAG(dag_id='downstream_dag', default_args=args)

ETL_HOME = '/home/prod/deepdive'
et = ExternalTaskSensor(
  external_dag_id='upstream_dag',
  external_task_id='upstream',
  dag=dag, 
  task_id='wait_for_upstream'
)

down = BashOperator(
    task_id='downstream',
    bash_command=(
        "export ETL_HOME=%(ETL_HOME)s; "
        " echo 'downstream_dag' "
    ) % {
        'ETL_HOME': ETL_HOME,
    },dag=dag)

down.set_upstream(et)
```

can you elaborate on what issue you're facing? As long as your upstream dag is called "upstream_dag" and the task your waiting for in that dag is called "upstream", your down task should start shortly after the upstream task has completed successfully... In the web ui the "et" Sensor should be running while the upstream task hasn't finished.

It was a shot in the dark to root cause issue #341 

It's curious how once we resolved the dependency, it started working, though there might be something else at play here. Do you folks test using the LocalExecutor or only the CeleryExecutor?

I just realized I was running the tests against SequentialExecutor and a sqlite db. I just switched my `unitests.cfg` to use LocalExecutor and a mysql database, that should speed up the process and cover LocalExecutor, which is much more important than SequentialExecutor.

Sorry, there is no need to re-open. pip wasn't seeing the 1.4.1 release tag and nor was git for some reason. I downloaded the zip of 1.4.1 from github and installed that via pip to get 1.4.1. Release 1.4.1 works as expected in relation to this issue.
Did `pip install airflow --upgrade` not upgrade for you? Should I be looking into this?

A mount point would work, using Kafka would work, dumping finished logs into s3 or HDFS would work for persistence/post execution access, ... We had a lot of internal discussion at some point on how to do this and based on the constraints I just implemented the current approach. It's been working very well, though one issue is clearly how a dying worker would bring it's logs in its grave.

We don't have filers or mount points in our environment here as they constitute single points of failure.

Assuming a mount point, it should be easy to serve the logs locally, I'd approve a PR that would add a configuration setting `LOG_FOLDER_MOUNTED = true` that would serve the logs from local when set to true.

I'm not much of a sys admin, but it seems easier and preferable to poke holes in the network than setting up a filer and mount points...

also using Local Executor

Appriciate for your help.

Yeah it works, schedule_interval is a DAG param, as in:

```
dag = DAG(dag_id='foo', schedule_interval=timedelta(hours=1))
```
Sorry, we cannot help with that. Try Googling your Redis issue, ask the Redis community, or defer to RabbitMQ...
Yes, from looking at the stack trace this seems to be an issue with SqlAlchemy and the MSSQL dialect and Python3 compatibility (newbytes), @jlowin, any input on this?

Great! I just wrote a little python tool here that helps us do bulk data reloads (and re-scoring/re-aggregation) for 30 days of data. It leverage the airflow CLI for parts of it. I needed to pass the "yes\n" to stdin using the function below. With your change, it saves me a few lines of code. Thanks again.

```
# Helper method to handle subprocess failures
def _call_subprocess_complex(command_as_list, stdin_input):
    command_as_string = ' '.join(command_as_list)
    logging.info("Running {}".format(command_as_string))
    p = Popen(command_as_list, stdin=PIPE)
    p_stdout = p.communicate(input=stdin_input)[0]
    logging.info(p_stdout)

    error_message = "FAILURE : %s" % command_as_string
    ret_code = p.returncode
    if ret_code != 0:
        logging.critical(error_message)
        exit(2)
```
![img](http://25.media.tumblr.com/tumblr_mddkdtUC1a1r9qnhbo1_250.gif)

Interesting... Future bytes object is supposed to be bulletproof but I guess an explicit typecheck could fail. I don't use mssql so I won't be able to test this directly but I will try to diagnose it tonight.

I agree with @tokenmathguy you can DIY with boto. However, it would be nice to encapsulate common AWS tasks in ready-made operators to deal with things like spinning up/down instances in auto-scaling groups or send messages to SQS ...
I guess that is part of the reason why type checks aren't pythonesque.

Operators and hooks are useful as a way to provide a simple/common interface to an underlying libraries, and hooks abstract away having to manage connection information or mechanics in your pipeline logic.

I also want to +1 this issue.  Pickling hasn't worked for me when using celery to send tasks to worker nodes.  We're using Airflow 1.5.  One comment which is a side note that didn't solve the problem is that we upgraded airflow from a previous version, and the column size of the pickle_hash was increased, so initially the column type was Int and it was changed to BigInt so that explained initially why things couldn't be unpickled.  
`ALTER TABLE dag_pickle MODIFY pickle_hash BIGINT;`

But after fixing that issue we still couldn't get unpickling to work.  Planning on digging into this more at some point when I've got more bandwidth.
Same issue with version 1.5.0

@fphhotchips I'm having trouble replicating this. Under Python 2.7, when I try to view `example_python_operator` and capture the values of the `task_ids` in `airflow/models.py:latest_execution_date`, they are all `str` (the expected behavior), not `newbytes`.

Here's what I'm doing, maybe you could do the same -- I'm sorry if this is more spelunking than you signed up for! You'll need `ipdb` (`pip install ipdb` if you don't have it). Your traceback shows line 1619 of `models.py` creating the error (the one that says `TI.task_id.in_(self.task_ids)`). If you go three lines above that (just after the one that creates the `session`), you can add a new line: 

``` python
session = ...
import ipdb; ipdb.set_trace() # new line
...
```

Save the file and start up the webserver again. Now when you try to view the DAG, your terminal (whichever one you started the webserver in) will open up a debugging window where you added the breakpoint. What is the output of typing `type(self.task_ids[0])`? I get `str`, but I think you must be getting `newbytes`... next step would be to figure out why.

@mistercrunch My major question is why can not run multiple SQL at the same time.
Such as my sql file have multiple SQL script slice by ;
Thx !

You cannot do that? only one sql command can be accept in mysql_hook.

I have reported it at
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/329

alright, that clarifies it. In this case I misunderstood the instructions for the mysql operator: 

'''sql (Can receive a str representing a sql statement, a list of str (sql statements), or reference to a template file. Template reference are recognized by str ending in ‘.sql’) – the sql code to be executed'''

thanks for clarification

You can pass it as a list of statements, but not a reference to a multi-statement sql script. DbApi doesn't seem to expose a standard way to run a script (multi-statements - separated by semicolons). That's usually a CLI feature.

Related:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4408714/execute-sql-file-with-python-mysqldb

So solutions are:
- Users break their scripts down into lists, either by parsing the file themselves (`f = open('foo.sql')`) in their pipeline script, or writing `sql = [...]` in their script
- The operator(s) logic could apply a regex that looks for semi-colons and breaks down the statements, trying to avoid the pitfalls (semi-colons in a sql string, ...)
- Writing alternate hooks that wraps the CLI (I think that's overkill, less desirable). That's what we did for Hive since we needed perfect compatibility there and had a lot of `hql` files to run.

For now option 1 works and doesn't require a new version out or anything...
Yeah that's better.

This is great, thanks for taking the time!

It should be very straightforward to add the operator on top of this hook.
Oh another note is you may want to add an `extras_require` for `oracle` in the `setup.py` file referencing cx_Oracle.

I tried use a plugin to fix it, however, it is not work for common. We could not override the class attribute in initialization.

``` python
import logging

from airflow.operators import PythonOperator
from airflow.utils import apply_defaults
from airflow.plugins_manager import AirflowPlugin

class PythonWithTemplatesOperator(PythonOperator):
    # template_fields = ('foo', 'bar')
    # template_ext = ('.sql')
    @apply_defaults
    def __init__(
            self,
            templates = dict(),
            template_ext = tuple(),
            *args, **kwargs):
        self.templates = templates
        for k in self.templates.keys():
            setattr(self, k, self.templates[k])
        self.__class__.template_fields = tuple(self.templates.keys())
        self.__class__.template_ext = template_ext
```

`[<type 'str'>, <class 'future.types.newstr.newstr'>, <class 'future.types.newstr.newstr'>, <class 'future.types.newstr.newstr'>, <class 'future.types.newstr.newstr'>, <class 'future.types.newstr.newstr'>, <class 'future.types.newstr.newstr'>, <class 'future.types.newstr.newstr'>, <class 'future.types.newstr.newstr'>, <class 'future.types.newstr.newstr'>, <class 'future.types.newstr.newstr'>]`

Awesome, I couldn't work out how to get at the task instance - didnt occur to me that you could actually reference it in the template. Brilliant work guys :smile_cat:

Here's the documentation reference to everything accessible in the templates (and in the "context" passed to operators):
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/code.html#macros

It sounds like subclassing `BaseExecutor` would be the way to go.

About your statement:
"We cannot run this command directly on our grid without installing Airflow there"

The state of the task instance is managed by the `airflow run` at the moment, and this encapsulation does quite a few things, from parsing your pipelines metadata, running the code in the operator and updating its status to "running" and "success". In light of that, the Airflow task instance needs the Airflow code to run Airflow jobs. 

So your options are to either install Airflow on those boxes, or somehow bootstrap it. To bootstrap it, you could highjack the `airflow run` call on that box to run code that would download and install airflow and then fire up the actual `airflow run`.

We could move the command generation from the `TaskInstance` class to `BaseExecutor` if you'd like to be able to control that though.

Alright, took your feedback and made some changes.
New code changes + cleanup + docs are up.
The try/except was basically because my base toolkit would generate a DNS on-the-fly if the TNS was not found. Should be good-to-go? (maybe check the re-worked and re-tested insert_rows func)

PS: just a general question, I have some operators based on this hook (transfer to Hive etc.), as well as other plugins (like an SFTPHook). What's the best way to share them with community?

So strange, I don't have that. I have a theory though -- if you open the file that creates the example (`example_python_operator.py`) and look near the bottom, you'll see a loop that creates the sleeping tasks.

The line that creates the task id is:

``` python
task_id='sleep_for_'+str(i),
```

Could you try changing it to:

``` python
task_id='sleep_for_{}'.format(i),
```

And let me know if your system is still creating `newstr` types? I'm not sure if this is it but I'm not sure how else it could only be affecting the sleep tasks and not the first one -- but that `str` is suspicious. Please let me know.

That fixes it. So essentially the `builtins.str` method that's imported at the top of the file gives a `<class 'future.types.newstr.newstr'>`, whereas just the regular `str` function gives type `str`. So, when you use the `'string'` syntax for `task_id='print_the_context'` you get a different type than when you used `str(i)`.

Mystery solved! Thanks for your help. 

Is it worth someone submitting an issue on pymssql?
Further, does changing the line above break anything (particularly Python 3 compatibility) in any way? I can't see that it would, but as noted above I'm not exactly an expert on the airflow codebase.

Ok, great!

I've been trying to make Airflow Py3 compatible without messing with the Py2 codebase too much. This depends heavily on the `future` library, which has lots of forwards/backwards-compatible objects (like `str`/`newstr`). Generally speaking, it "does the right thing" and doesn't interfere -- but sometimes it doesn't work (like here!). I'll submit a PR very soon to fix this behavior.

And changing that line is totally fine -- but we want to fix this at a deeper level to make sure no one does it by accident. Sorry you had to encounter this bug!

@fphhotchips I think this particular problem has already been fixed in the latest version of Airflow -- @mistercrunch removed the problematic line in https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/3b357487e74afc2ca4705abf1be7bc1708cddc44. Could you try upgrading and see if it goes away? Meanwhile, I will look for any similar issues. Thanks!

I really prefer for the unit of work to take care of its own state, message queues can drop messages. At the moment it's somewhat of a relief to know that the executor can be consider mostly stateless (if the executor goes down, the state is mostly safe as the workers will maintain the state of the tasks regardless of the shape of the executor or the message queue). There's also a mechanism by which task instances emit a regular heartbeat so that we can identify zombie tasks, that's all part of the wrapping and there are strong assumptions there. Changing these assumptions mean changing some code, generating new bugs and having to develop new ways to resync the state when it gets unsync. 

So if you want to run airflow you need to have Airflow on the worker, there just are no clean ways around it.

The problem is that there's a postgres specific bug (no exception autocast as str) in the except block...
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/376

I did add try catchall block. This should prevent even exceptions in underlying except blocks.
closes https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/357

Variables may be used across DAG. What's great with a key value store is the simplicity and that you define your own conventions. A clean convention may be to have a single json object for each dag_id that has all the variables for that DAG. Or maybe allowing for a category or tags field in the variable model so that you can filter on that, but that's not super high value.... I think if you have hundreds or thousands of Airflow variables you probably need to rethink the way you want to organize this metadata.
Could we support the PLAIN auth under use_beeline mode?
Yes, but I can't develop it since I can't test it. It should be easy for you to add support for this.

https://pythonconquerstheuniverse.wordpress.com/2012/02/15/mutable-default-arguments/

It's not Heroku, but a Heroku-like environment in a corporate data center.

It has been a pretty easy setup.  The only things that I have had to implement are:

**Rewriting the configuration file based on the environment (UI, worker, or scheduler) prior to service launch**.  I needed to do this in order to inject the randomized port number, postgres url, redis url, etc into the config.  Now there is support for loading configuration from the environment (issue #285 ) which should obviate the need for this.

**Add the environment variable C_FORCE_ROOT=1 to the workers**.  It runs as root, and Celery complains because pickle+root=danger.

The log shipping is the only thing left for me to resolve, and I'm not sure I have a good solution right now.

@mistercrunch, I definitely think that many dynamic-workflow use cases could be met with on-demand execution of a dag.  In my experience, there often exist entire "plates" of tasks that you'd like to repeat for a series of triggers, while using dag logic like Airflow's to resolve dependencies within each plate.  Airflow's DAGs represent blocks of known dependencies that are symmetric when unrolled over time; these "plates" are just the same thing unrolled over some axis other than time.

Letting us define a DAG once but then manually schedule it would maintain the invariant that the entire structure is known in between runs.  Since task lists would be invariant, the cool analytics across instances would still work.  (IMO these analytics are a killer feature for AirFlow, and unfortunately the "dynamically generate a new DAG for each run" approach above would lose that.)  If we could stamp an arbitrary label on these runs/instances, and/or have another way of passing some metadata into them that would be accessible to operators in the `context` variable, my life would be complete!

I read through the code to see how this gets wired in and I'm a little scared to blindly merge it.

Which kwarg does `os.environ` end up in?
thanks, it should looks ok now

@georgebdavis I totally agree. This should become the next big item on the roadmap.

"Analytics as a service" where for example a data scientist would order prepared data set based on specific metadata is a use case we want to support as a first class citizen. Or simply batching your DAG execution based on events instead of fixed time is totally reasonable and should be supported. Many companies run workflows whenever a batch shows up and instantiate a dag for each batch.

I think there's potentially two new things here: "externally triggered DAGs", assuming a similar DAG structure across instances, and "singleton DAGs" that may have a very different shape over different instances, so much so that we may want different dag_ids to represent them.

The "externally triggered DAGs" could be implemented fairly easily by:
- adding a DAG level parameter `externally_triggered=True` 
- creating a new metadata table that would associate a `batch_id` to a specific timestamp `trigger_dttm`
- altering the tree view's x axis to deal with variable schedule interval
- altering the scheduler and dependency engine to understand that it needs to look at the  batch_id table to move in time and find previous and next runs
- exposing way to trigger a batch_id (REST/CLI)
- ...
![img](http://www.reactiongifs.us/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/thumbs_up_okay_daft_punk.gif)

Thanks @mistercrunch.  I'd be happy to contribute to the dev on that.  Maybe an initial step would be creating that new metadata table and the call that writes to it?  

One thought for that "...": if the scheduler is discovering the next run time from the metadata table, we need to make sure any write to that table (e.g. the trigger call) wakes up the scheduler to find out if its next move has changed.

`os.environ` doesn't end up in a kwarg. It ends up in `*args` so that you have the equivalent of this:

```
ConfigParser(os.environ)
```
